awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal - PREEVENTS Track 2: Cascadia Scenario Earthquakes: Source, Path, and implications for Earthquake Early Warning
awd_abstract_narration:
The Cascadia Subduction Zone is a 1200 km-long plate boundary that is capable of hosting a magnitude 9 megathrust earthquake and is the greatest source of seismic and tsunami hazard in the Pacific Northwest. One very pressing issue is accurate estimation of potential ground motions because they are a predictor of damage resulting from an earthquake and can guide emergency response. In Cascadia, current ground motion predictions do not incorporate the physical processes governing earthquake rupture on the plate interface or account for realistic 3D wave propagation in the Earth's crust. The project aims to predict strong ground motions resulting from a magnitude 9 earthquake in the Pacific Northwest by combining physics-based earthquake models and realistic estimates of wave propagation. The predicted ground motions will be used to test the currently operating version of ShakeAlert, the West Coast Earthquake Early Warning system. This project will provide state-of-the-art scientific information about possible Cascadia scenario earthquakes to local residents and help stakeholders make informed decisions to improve earthquake resilience in the Pacific Northwest. The research will facilitate substantial collaboration among three early career female professors, four students (graduate and undergraduate students), and two postdoctoral researchers. Additionally, it builds an effective communication framework between earthquake source, ground motion, and early warning communities to promote a comprehensive methodology for seismic hazard mitigation.

The prediction of earthquake ground motions requires fundamental understanding of earthquake source dynamics and accurate estimation of wave propagation path effects. Previous ground motion predictions for megathrust earthquakes either rely on empirical relations that are not well constrained by data in this region or simulate wave propagation assuming a certain kinematic rupture history that does not necessarily satisfy the physics of dynamic ruptures. Moreover, previous calculations strongly rely on the accuracy of a velocity model, in which realistic wave propagation through fore-arc and sedimentary basins is not well represented. Finally, both realistic source processes and accurate wave propagation are necessary to establish reliable information in the seismic waveform for earthquake early warning. The project will construct a suite of realistic scenario earthquakes that could occur in the Cascadia Subduction Zone using an innovative three-stage approach. First, the most up-to-date knowledge of properties of the Cascadia Subduction Zone (e.g. geometry, coupling and stress conditions) will be incorporated in fully dynamic rupture simulations to determine the influence of each of these factors on rupture history and to construct a suite of potential rupture histories for a magnitude 9 earthquake. The earthquake source models will then be combined with Green?s functions derived from the ambient seismic field to estimate ground motions in major population centers in the Pacific Northwest. Finally, the project will explore the implications of these ground motions for earthquake early warning algorithms that are currently under development.
org_div_long_name: Integrative and Collaborative Education and Research (ICER)

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
Megathrust earthquakes (M>8) and tsunamis in subduction zones, where one tectonic plate subducts beneath the other, cause the greatest damage and are of primary interest in hazard mitigation. Physics-based rupture simulations can be applied to subduction zones where megathrust earthquakes were not yet recorded by modern instruments, but abundant geological and geophysical observations are available to constrain fault properties. We have developed 2D and 3D dynamic rupture simulations for the Cascadia subduction zone, a 1200 km-long plate boundary capable of hosting an M9 earthquake. Cascadia megathrust earthquakes have received considerable attention as major hazards for densely populated regions in the Pacific Northwest. The simulations improve our understanding of Cascadia earthquake hazards by predicting potential ground shaking during future events. 

Through 2D rupture simulations, we have quantified how the transition region that separates the locked region from the slow-slip region influences rupture depth extents. The transition region is usually assumed to be a barrier for rupture propagation and thus reduces onshore ground shaking. We have shown instead that Cascadia rupture can propagate through the transition region at fast speeds. We have also developed the first 3D dynamic rupture simulations based on the current understanding of velocity model, fault geometry, fault stress, and frictional properties. The initial stress condition is constrained by geodetic coupling models that represent the distribution of interseismic strain build-up. The simulations indicate that the final size of simulated earthquakes strongly depends on the amount of strain build-up in the central Cascadia region and fault friction at shallow depths. A subset of our simulations can also closely match the coastal subsidence data recorded from the most recent Cascadia megathrust earthquake in 1700. Our results stress the importance of geophysical monitoring efforts in central Cascadia and the regions close to the trench, which will be instrumental for improving the predictive capability of our simulations.

We have also evaluated tsunami hazards from M7.5–9.2 Cascadia earthquakes using tsunami simulations constrained by earthquake rupture physics and geodetic coupling models. We have systematically varied the geographic extent and slip of earthquake rupture in tsunami simulations to identify the subduction zone segments that contribute most to tsunami propagation. The simulations demonstrate that the concave geometry of the Pacific Northwest coastline focuses tsunami energy between latitudes 44o and 45o in Oregon.While it is often believed that the worst-case tsunami scenario results from the largest M9 earthquake, our results highlight the importance of considering M>8.5 earthquakes for tsunami hazard mitigation, as they can create comparable coastal tsunami amplitudes due to the focusing effect of the concave coastline geometry.

This project supports the collaboration among three early career female scientists as well as graduate students and postdoctoral scholars from diverse backgrounds. It also supports the training of an undergraduate student through the IRIS Undergraduate Internship Program. By modeling earthquake rupture in Cascadia subduction zones, graduate student Marlon Ramos has developed advanced skills in computer programming and data processing. He is currently a National Research Council Postdoctoral Fellow at the Air Force Research Lab. This project also provides a unique training opportunity for postdoctoral scholar Amir Salaree to develop tsunami simulations based on earthquake source physics, which is of great importance for integrating earthquake and tsunami hazard research and promoting communication between different research communities.

 


Last Modified: 11/02/2021
Modified by: Yihe Huang
